work.name: Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton University
work.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Best Technology Award of AI Hackathon Competition
Excellent Student Cadre, Merit Student, Excellent Graduate Award
Silver Medal of The 45th International Collegiate Programming Contest Asia Regional Contest (ICPC)
Gold Award of "Challenge Cup" National College Student Business Plan Competition

publications.name: Efficient Decoding for Long Prompts via Low-Rank Attention
publications.summary: We explore the potential of applying low-rank techniques to prompt decoding. First, we verify that existing low-rank methods are applicable to prompt decoding with low approximation error, both theoretically and empirically. Second, we unearth and implement efficient decoding algorithms from literature across various fields. Moreover, we propose a linear-complexity algorithm that achieves SOTA time and memory efficiency, and make an IO-aware implementation by Triton.

publications.name: All We Need Are Requirement Engineering and Testing? Experimenting a New Programming Practice with LLMs
publications.summary: Build an LLM-based Agent that can automatically finish the process of Software Engieering by taking a user requirement as input.

publications.name: A software for the designing of the installation of photoelectrocatalytic building materials and flexible solar cells
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
